University of California, Berkeley

UC Berkeley was founded in 1868 as the first university established west of the Mississippi River. It offers more than 200 undergraduate majors and programs, and its graduate schools offer more than 100 master’s degrees and doctoral degrees.

The state constitution of California envisioned a university that would “contribute even more than California’s gold to the glory and happiness of advancing generations,” which was the inspiration for Berkeley’s creation.

In 1873, the colors gold and blue were chosen for Berkeley, with blue representing not only the sky and ocean of California but also the Yale graduates who helped establish the school; gold California is known as the “Golden State.”

The university has approximately 27,000 undergraduate and 10,000 postgraduate students and is situated in the Bay Area of San Francisco.

There have been 19 Nobel Prizes awarded to Berkeley faculty members, the majority of them in the fields of physics, chemistry, and economics. Saul Perlmutter, who led a team that discovered the accelerating expansion of the universe and suggested the existence of a form of dark energy that accounts for 75% of the universe, was awarded the 2011 Nobel Prize for Physics. and George Akerlof, who was awarded the Prize for Economics in 2001 for demonstrating how markets fail when sellers and buyers have different access to information.

Jack London, a novelist and journalist, Gregory Peck, an Oscar-winning actor, Zulfikar Ali Bhutto, a former Pakistani prime minister and president, Joan Didion, and Alex Morgan, a US footballer who won the Women’s World Cup, are among the notable alumni.

Berkeley has a custom as a focal point of political activism. The campus was a hotbed of student protests against the Vietnam War in the 1960s and 1970s.

The 1890-built Botanic Garden and the 60,000-seat California Memorial Stadium, which is where the university’s sports teams play, are among the campus attractions.

The Berkeley sports teams are represented by the Golden Bear.

Berkeley’s donning ability was exhibited at the 2012 Olympics in London, when its alumni won 17 awards – 11 gold, one silver and five bronze. Together with France and Germany, Berkeley would have ranked joint sixth in the gold medal table if it had been a nation.

University of Michigan

The University of Michigan has been ranked among the top ten universities in the world by QS World Rankings since 2013. In addition to being one of the largest research institutions in the United States, U-M also ranks highly in student satisfaction and academic quality.

Harvard University

Harvard University was founded in 1636 as the Collegiate School, and became Harvard College in 1701. It is located in Cambridge, Massachusetts, and is the oldest institution of higher education in the United States.

Stanford University

Founded in 1885 by Leland Stanford Jr., the university has grown into one of the world’s leading research institutions. Located in Palo Alto, California, Stanford is home to more than 40 academic departments and centers, with an enrollment of nearly 30,000 undergraduate and graduate students.

Yale University

Yale University was founded in 1701 as King George’s College, and became Yale College in 1718. It is located in New Haven, Connecticut, United States.
